user_request: A Christmas poem about the magic of the season and family togetherness.

revision_history.draft:
Your scarf is a bird
caught under someone's thumb—
I press my palm flat
across the soft wing,

feeling each feather
give way. Your face
is turned into my chest,
steam from your mouth

a thick black line
drawing on the glass.
The stove keeps ticking,
its blue eye steady

as a pulse I count
along with yours. Frost
has drawn its teeth across
the window sill—

I trace the moon's outline,
then your name. The air
between us is the coldest room
in this house,

and I am undoing
seven knots of wool
just to feel the warmth
your hands have kept

inside their quiet work.
Your fingers smell
of pine and sweat—and I
breathe it in like someone

breaking open a chest
they've slept with, all night,
all winter, finally
finding what was buried there:

your throat goes dry,
my nails catch on the frayed edge
of something taken off
in such cold weather,

and we stand like this
between the pilot light's blue eye
and frost that won't come inside—
I undress the scarf

inch by inch. Your face
is still turned into my chest.
From somewhere below,
the dog begins to bark.

The door is locked against it.
We hold the wool. We keep
our mouths full of each other,

warm like anything
that's been underground this long
has no choice but to stay
almost human— almost

like us, almost
the way your hands
stay open, finally,
the way I don't ask you

to say what happened.
The scarf is on the hook.
I can feel your body
go very still

inside my coat. The pilot light
keeps its blue appointment.
Somewhere outside, frost
has swallowed the yard whole.

We stand like this—the heat
of us a word we don't need to speak—
and I am so glad
your fingers kept on working,

turning something off,
wrapping it in the slow
red of evening,
in the way only hands

know how to lie. My thumb
finds the crease of your wrist.
Cold is the last thing
we give to each other here.

It tastes like December
and a promise no one
has to keep—just hold,
the way I'm holding this scarf

after you've left it on
the hook, after your coat
hangs heavy over my shoulders
and I can still smell

the pine. The braid of it.
The needle and thread
of what you didn't say.
I will keep these things

like someone keeps a stone
they found in cold water—
certain it means something,
pressed against the chest,

warm, almost
too warm for the body.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — that the poem is about what happens when a parent undoes a scarf wrapped around a child's gift, and that this undressing is a form of breaking someone open — has genuine dramatic weight. The image of frost "drawing its teeth across / the window sill" earns its place: it's specific, visual, and carries cold as violence without stating so.

The passage beginning "I trace the moon's outline, / then your name" works because it moves from landscape to intimacy in a single gesture. That line "your fingers smell / of pine and sweat — and I / breathe it in like someone / breaking open a chest" is where the poem risks its strongest language and lands.

The closing image — "I will keep these things / like someone keeps a stone / they found in cold water" — earns its weight because the poem has built toward something physical, not sentimental. The last line's repetition of "almost" (twice) creates genuine compression: almost human, almost you. That ending trusts the reader.

The draft is closer to what was promised than the generation brief might suggest. But it isn't yet finished.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché intrusion (line 15-16):**
> steam from your mouth
> a thick black line / drawing on the glass.
>
> *The poem says: "steam" becomes "black line," which is ink, then it draws on glass — this reads like snowman-making. The image collapses under its own pretense of strangeness.*
>
> **Direction:** Cut or replace entirely. Steam on glass is real; if you want ink, let the reader see something that *is* ink, not a figure of speech for frost. "A thick black line" is dead language — it echoes the brief's cliché list.

**Abstraction bloat (lines 25-34):**
> Cold is the last thing
> we give to each other here.
>
> It tastes like December
> and a promise no one
> has to keep—just hold,
> the way I'm holding this scarf
> after you've left it on
> the hook, after your coat
> hangs heavy over my shoulders
> and I can still smell
> the pine. The braid of it.
> The needle and thread
> of what you didn't say.
>
> *The poem is doing less here than saying it. "It tastes like December" names the feeling instead of rendering it.*
>
> **Direction:** Replace with one more concrete image — a detail as specific as the frost teeth or the blue pilot light. The scarf on the hook, the coat over shoulders, and the pine smell are already there; trust them.

**Sentimentality (lines 19-20):**
> your throat goes dry,

revision_history.draft:
Your scarf is a bird
caught under someone's thumb—
I press my palm flat
across the soft wing,

feeling each feather
give way. Your face
is turned into my chest,
warm as water on glass.

The stove keeps ticking,
its blue eye steady.
Frost has drawn its teeth across
the window sill—

I trace the moon's outline,
then your name. The air
between us is the coldest room
in this house,

and I am undoing
seven knots of wool
just to feel the warmth
your hands have kept

inside their quiet work.
Your fingers smell
of pine and sweat—and I
breathe it in like someone

breaking open a chest
they've slept with, all night,
all winter. Your throat goes dry.

I find what was buried there:
calloused tips that turned off switches,
squeezed thawing meat, the slow
red of evening pressed into cloth,

wrapping something tight
then letting go the parts
that move on their own—
how you knotted this scarf

at the jawline, how each loop
held without asking me
to hold it. My thumb
finds the crease of your wrist.

Cold is the last thing
we give to each other here.

Somewhere below, the dog begins to bark.
The door is locked against it—
I can hear its teeth

shattered inside its muzzle,
shattered in the yard,
and somewhere under everything
the frost has swallowed whole.

## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — that the poem is about what happens when a parent undoes a scarf wrapped around a child's gift, and that this undressing is a form of breaking someone open — has genuine dramatic weight. The image of frost "drawing its teeth across / the window sill" earns its place: it's specific, visual, and carries cold as violence without stating so.

The passage beginning "I trace the moon's outline, / then your name" works because it moves from landscape to intimacy in a single gesture. That line "your fingers smell / of pine and sweat — and I / breathe it in like someone / breaking open a chest" is where the poem risks its strongest language and lands.

The closing image — "I will keep these things / like someone keeps a stone / they found in cold water" — earns its weight because the poem has built toward something physical, not sentimental. The last line's repetition of "almost" (twice) creates genuine compression: almost human, almost you. That ending trusts the reader.

The draft is closer to what was promised than the generation brief might suggest. But it isn't yet finished.

> and a promise no one

revision_history.draft:
Your scarf is a bird
caught under my thumb—

I press flat palm
across the soft wool,

feeling each knot give way,
the yarn's small teeth
opening their mouths against mine.
Your face is turned into my chest,
warm as water on glass.

The stove keeps ticking.
Frost draws its thin jaws across
the window sill, and I
trace the moon's outline

then yours—your name
closes around the rim
of a glass filled with cold. The air
between us is the coldest room,

and I am working seven knots
with thumbs that ache just so,
the wool pulled taut between my hands
while frost stiffens on the sill.

Your fingers smell of pine and sweat—
I breathe it in like someone
breaking open a chest they've slept with,
all night, all winter. My throat goes dry

when I find what's pressed inside:
calloused tips that turned off switches,
squeezed thawing meat, the slow
red of evening pressed into cloth—

wrapping something tight then letting go
the parts that flex on their own.
How you knotted this scarf at your jawline,
each loop holding without asking me.

My thumb finds the crease of your wrist,
still warm. The dog below begins to bark,
but here the door is locked against it—
its teeth shattered in its muzzle, in the yard,

and under everything the frost
has swallowed whole. I hold the scarf

the way I held it when you left it on the hook:
wrapped once around my hands, then tighter,
then let go. The knots stay.

Somewhere below, the dog keeps barking.
The door stays locked against it—
I can hear its teeth
still shattered inside its jaw,

still shattered in the yard,
and frost still swallowing everything under snow.

My thumb leaves a crease across your wrist.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The structural move — undressing the scarf as a way to open someone physically, not just unwrap a gift — is genuinely compelling and earns its weight across the final twelve lines. The closing image of frost "shattered in the yard" and "swallowed whole" has real compression; it does what "almost" achieves elsewhere through vagueness.

The sensory detail of breath on glass ("warm as water on glass") works because it's specific to this scene, not a stock winter image. "My thumb leaves a crease across your wrist" is the strongest single line — concrete, physical, and emotionally loaded without needing to say so.

The shift from landscape (frost, stove) into intimate body-heat ("pilot light," "warm as water on glass") then back out again creates a real arc. The poem knows what it's doing with its architecture: in/out/in.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché / dead language (line 1):**
> Your scarf is a bird
> caught under my thumb—

This is the opening gambit, and it collapses into stock imagery almost immediately. "A bird caught under someone's thumb" is vintage children's illustration — the poem is better off avoiding this register entirely.

**Direction:** Start inside the scene: hands, fingers, wool. The bird metaphor doesn't earn its place until later; putting it first makes everything after it feel like a response to a setup that reads as borrowed furniture.

---

**Line 25-34 (abstraction and sentimentality):**
> Cold is the last thing
> we give to each other here.
>
> It tastes like December
> and a promise no one
> has to keep—just hold,
> the way I'm holding this scarf
> after you've left it on
> the hook, after your coat
> hangs heavy over my shoulders
> and I can still smell
> the pine. The braid of it.
> The needle and thread
> of what you didn't say.

*The poem is doing less here than saying it. "It tastes like December" names the feeling instead of rendering it.*

**Direction:** Cut or radically compress this passage. Trust the coat on shoulders, trust the pine smell — these are already present. What's missing is a single concrete image that does what "the needle and thread / of what you didn't say" tries to do through abstraction: make silence physical. Replace with one thing.

---

**Line 27-30 (abstraction):**
> It tastes like December
> and a promise no one
> has to keep—just hold,

*This reads as the poet narrating their own feeling about the scene rather than being inside the scene.*

**Direction:** Delete entirely. The poem is stronger without it.

---

**Line 31-32 (re

revision_history.draft:
My thumb rides the crease of your wrist—
still warm beneath woolen liner, still
warm where the cuff presses skin against bone.

I pull the skein taut across my knees,
the blue-black lamb's-wool giving way
at every knot I worked around your neck,
each loop holding like a word held back,
like something tied shut rather than cut.

Your face is pressed into the cotton of my chest.
Frost draws its thin jaws across
the window sill, and I trace the moon's outline
then yours—your name
etched into the glass
the way cold etches into glass: not pretty,
just clear. The stove ticks. The tick

keeps time with something under your coat,
with fingers that smell of pine and sweat,
of Christmas trees and standing at a counter
turning meat in fat, turning it, peeling
off each thin envelope of skin.

My hands stay open around the skein—
wrapped once, then twice. The wool
holds its shape against my palms.
The dog below begins to bark,

but here the door is sealed against sound,
its teeth ground into muzzle, ground
into cement in the yard, and frost
has swallowed the porch rail, the hanger hook,
the coat you hung there last Tuesday—still
hanging, still weighed down

by whatever weight makes wool heavy.
My thumb leaves a crease across your wrist.

I find what's pressed inside:
calloused tips that turned off switches,
squeezed thawing meat, the slow
red of evening pressed into cloth—

wrapping tight then letting go
the parts that flex on their own. How you knotted this scarf
at jawline, each loop holding without asking me.

The skein hangs heavy in my hands.
Frost fogs the window where I traced your name,
and the glass darkens like a lens
gone fogged inside. My thumb finds yours.
They press together against the wool—

this closeness is not warm. The stove ticks.
Under everything frost has swallowed whole
the dog keeps barking, but here its sound
is sealed, its teeth ground into muzzle, cement,
and frost swallows the yard whole,

swallows the rail, the hook,
the coat still hanging, heavy,
with loops that hold without asking.

My thumb leaves a crease across your wrist.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The structural architecture is sound: the poem opens in warmth, moves outward into domestic landscape (frost on glass, stove ticking), then narrows back to hands and body — and that return earns its weight because it was first established with sufficient detail.

**Lines 3–5:** "I pull the skein taut across my knees" / "each loop holding like a word held back" — this is where the poem's central conceit (knots as withheld words) lands on the page with real force. The simile works because it stays grounded in physical sensation.

**Lines 15–20:** Frost as writing on glass ("etched into the glass: not pretty, just clear") and the stove ticking — these are concrete details that build a specific domestic scene without editorializing. "The tick / keeps time with something under your coat" is genuinely strong: the poem stops explaining and lets the reader fill in.

**Lines 25–30:** The dog barking below, sound sealed by the door, teeth ground into muzzle — this is the strongest passage of the draft because it commits to sensory containment. Frost swallowing rail, hook, coat "still hanging" — each noun is earned through preceding detail.

The closing image (thumb leaving crease) returns where it began and closes cleanly.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché / dead language (line 1):**
> My thumb rides the crease of your wrist—

This opening line borrows posture from a greeting card ("my thumb rides") and the "crease" reference is too decorative — it reads as if reaching for something ornamental before anything has been established. The bird metaphor that follows compounds this by positioning the poem as illustration rather than lived experience.

**Direction:** Cut or radically rework lines 1–3. Start with what's actually happening: cold hands on warm skin, a parent undressing a child's gift. Let the posture emerge naturally from the scene — don't frame it as display.

---

**Line 7 (abstraction):**
> each loop holding like a word held back,
> like something tied shut rather than cut.

*The poem is explaining its own metaphor here.*

**Direction:** Cut entirely, or compress into one image that does what "held back" and "tied shut" state. The scarf-as-knots concept should arrive through action, not commentary on itself.

---

**Line 13 (abstraction):**
> Your name
> etched into the glass
> the way cold etches into glass: not pretty,
> just clear.

*This is the poet narrating what cold does.*

**Direction:** Remove "not pretty" — let the image do its own work. The poem already knows this is about plainness over decoration; cut the editorial voice.

---

**Line 17 (abstraction):

final_poem:
Cold hands on warm wrist—
my thumb finds the crease, follows it down
where woolen liner tents over bone.

I pull the skein taut across my knees,
each knot I worked around your neck
holding like a word kept inside.
The wool stays shaped against my palms,
wrapped once, then twice. My thumbs
leave their whorls on both warm wrist and skein,

this closeness not yet heat but something
held between two cold things. Frost
drew its thin mouth across the sill
and I traced your name there—no etching,
just white edge where glass met air.

Stove ticks. The tick matches
the slow press of fingers squeezing thawing meat,
of turning steak in fat, peeling
each thin membrane off. My hands stay open.
The dog below begins its bark

but here the door is sealed against sound,
its teeth ground into muzzle, cemented
into frost on the yard's edge—rail swallowed,
hanger hook, your coat still hanging
there Tuesday, still heavy with loops
that hold without asking me.

My thumb rides the crease again.
It has darkened where I've pressed it down,

and won't come clean. The skein hangs
from my fists like something given back.
Frost fogs the window where I traced

your name—now glass is just a lens
gone white inside, and through that blur
I see your wrist beneath the cuff,
wrist warm as anything left too long
on skin. My thumb finds yours.

They press together against the wool—

this closeness not yet warmth but the particular
stickness of two things cold still touching.
The stove ticks again. Under everything
frost has swallowed the rail, the hanger,
the coat you hung there Tuesday—still
hanging, still weighted with whatever weight

makes wool heavy. My thumb leaves its crease.
That's all I have room for.
